description: From Middle French coutelas, from Old French coutel (“knife”) + -as (augmentative suffix).

entries.meaning: (nautical) A short sword with a curved blade, and a convex edge; once used by sailors when boarding an enemy ship.
examples: She could feel Tern’s stare fixed right between her shoulder blades, and knew he was aching to plunge his cutlass there.

entries.meaning: A similarly shaped tool; a machete.

verbs.description: cutlass (third-person singular simple present cutlasses, present participle cutlassing, simple past and past participle cutlassed)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To cut back (vegetation) with a cutlass.
